cells.data:
Intro to Javascript

Hey everyone, how was your superbowl weekend? This weekend I started to learn javascript through CodeAcademy. I am still following "The Project Odin," This week it has me going over the basics of javascript. It is scheduled to take about 7-10 hrs to run through the course, i expect to have a decent foundation after i complete this course. 

So Far

At this point I am about 30% overall complete and I had to take a break to jot down some notes before i get overwhelm. So far i noticed the syntax is little weird but i am getting comfortable with it, i keep forgetting the damn comma after the parenhesis. 

NOTES

9:48 PM

• What is a scripting language?
    - A programming language that supports scripts??probably should elaborate on that.
• What is a variable?
    - Variables are used to store objects

• What is a string? An array? A boolean?
    - A string is words or whole numbers between quotes.
    - An array is a list of objects.
    - A boolean is true or false statement.
• What are events?
    - Haven't learned this yet...

Modulo

I am not sure what modulo is used for? the guide says modulo is used for testing divisibility, whatever that might be good for.

.length

Adds up the total number of characters used

mark.length === 4

prompt

ask the user a question

console.log

Prints out whatever is written in the (). 

.Substrings(x, y)

used for when you don’t want to display the entire string. “x” is where you start and “y” is where you finish. sort of like cropping.

Where is gets tricky is the numbering of x and y. 

To select “wo” in “world”, you should write. “world”. substring(0, 2)

Remember that 0 is a number so it goes 0 1 2. so think of 0 being before the letters start. “0”w”1”o”2”r”3”l”4”d”5” in order to only print out “wo” we need whats in-between 0-2.

More examples:

console.log("January".substring(0,3)) console.log("Melbourne is great".substring(0,12)) console.log("Hamburgers".substring(3,10))

Variables

Use var to declare your variable then a single =. 

var myAge = 28; console.log(myAge);

Other Examples:

confirm("I am ready to play!")

var age = prompt("What's your age");

if (age < 13)

{ console.log("You are too young to play the game."); }

else

{ console.log("Let's get ready to play!"); }

End of my notes.

Now off to learn about functions.

~Mark
